Params[3]: That's great, Noan!
Hearing about what just happened, Field feels genuinely happy for Noan.
What are you gonna do, though?
I'll just stay here. There are so many books I like here, and I have you coming by like this to tell me about your day, too.
Hey, why the long face? I consider myself lucky for being able to stay here to wait for things to get better.
I mean, considering what my dad did...
You mean Bancroft?
His boy has got nothing to do with it, but the man himself has definitely got some issues.
The man himself has definitely got some issues—these words punch him so hard in the belly he felt nauseous, because this is exactly how people described him and his mother just not too long ago.
I've been looking for arms dealers to work with, but he'd always find out about it every time I made a move.
Arms dealers, you said?
Right. See, the weapons the Cargo Crew uses are things that the guys up there don't need anymore or are simply too old
It's a real pain in the butt fighting the Corrupted and bandits we come across on our missions with those weapons. Just try to imagine how we'd fare fighting the guys up there with them.
They're just going to keep coming back down here to screw us over if we don't have what it takes to stop them.
Is that our only way out, though?

Yes, it is. The royal family is nothing but an empty shell now as it is, and the aristocrats that are still around have all sided with Ashlar. Trying to work things out peacefully with them is a waste of time because they don't give a damn about people's lives.
And given how dire the situation is out there, we can't really ask any external forces to come and help us deal with ACA—in other words, we're on our own, and we need arms to fend for ourselves.
Now... we need to hurry up because things are only going to work to our disadvantage if we let them drag on. About Bancroft, though...
Right, the kid you saved before is his son, right?
Yes.
Ugh... Never mind.
I'm not going to ask you to stop hanging out with him, but I want you to keep your mouth zipped about what I tell you.
Right, of course.
I'll be away again for some time, and I want you to continue with your training while I'm away.
Yes, Captain!
Seeing her about to step out, Noan suddenly remembers a question he wanted to ask.
...What do we need to do to get our hands on those weapons?
People are barely able to keep their heads above water now with the Punishing Virus wreaking havoc. How exactly are we supposed to get these weapons we need to fight the guards from above?

Some of the factories and secondhand markets in the hidden alleys around the reservation areas might have such weapons, but how in the world does Rachel have the resources in exchange for all the weapons they need?
Sitting beside his friends, Noan tries to get to the bottom of the riddle.
How, you asked? Haha, I've got extra pay here.
What Rachel said pops into his mind.
Extra pay...?
It's true that I've crossed the line, but if what I did brings about a better tomorrow for the people, I'd gladly do it again and pay the price.
I-is... this why?
Are you helping her, Mom?
Yes. I'm trying to help her... I don't always agree with the way she does things, but I have no right to question her, either.
The boy is starting to piece the puzzle together.
Mom went down that path to help Rachel get the resources she needed to get those weapons.
...Isn't there another way out?
Why did they have to poison her if this is the truth? And... just how is Rachel supposed to get all the resources she needs with Julie now dead?
Two months later.
Bancroft—Field's father—is finally back home from his mission. He's meeting up with Field and Noan.
...I gave Barbra the chef from the Logistics Crew some resources hoping she'd look after Field when I wasn't around, but man...
Barbra the chef?
Yes, the one that's super close to Assad.
I see them together all the time, and my hunch is that they're getting married soon...
Seems like I was totally wrong about her. Anyhow, thank you for saving my son.
Of course.
Totally forgot to introduce myself. I'm Bancroft, and we worked at a pharmaceutical factory around a reservation area before—until Corrupted assaulted the place and killed my wife...
I've already told him all that, Dad.
You did? Seems like you've found yourself a good buddy, son.
Right.
Sir, is it true that you know Ashlar from the upper level?

Well, I do know those that work for Ashlar, but our relationship is mostly business-oriented. When we left our reservation area, we brought him some semi-finished products from the dilapidated factory.
Probably a good idea to tell people that sooner than later. People down here don't exactly like those guys, so...
Right, of course... Thank you.
Bancroft looks away with a frown, seeming as though he was about to say more.
Sir?
Oh, hey. I mean, sure. I'll keep that in mind.
And please don't even lend them a hand.
Worried, Noan recalls what Rachel said to him.
R-right.
The man now seems a little flustered.
By the way, can I ask you to take care of Field for just a few more days while I'm out on another delivery mission with Team 41?
I'll come here to pick him up as soon as we find ourselves a permanent spot.
No problem at all, sir. We're good friends.
Yup.
Everything going well with your missions these days, Dad?
Bancroft frowns again when Field brings up the subject.
What's wrong, Dad?
Nothing.
You've never been good at lying, Dad.
I probably can't help you physically, but I can still give you ideas. Kids have helped solve some of history's most difficult puzzles—remember you were the one that told me this?
You're right.
Well, things don't look good these days. The cargo box we use for delivery is getting old, and it got a piece of it blown off when we got attacked the other night.
We realized we'd lost a bunch of goods when we were done cleaning up the Corrupted and checked on the cargo box.
It's not the first time the Cargo Crew let things go missing.
These words suddenly pop into Noan's mind—words that his mother said to Rachel a long time ago.
I'm guessing it was some Scavenger on the verge of dying that did that, although I have no evidence to say so definitely.
Did you check the camcorder?
No, son, we don't have that. I heard they only carry a camcorder when they're delivering valuable goods.
Is it expensive to make one?

I had the same thought actually, but people's theory is that we just won't bother trying to catch the perps anyways even if we have them on the camcorder, because they're mostly just homeless Scavengers.
The security rules here are a little different from the pharmaceutical factory's. It's safe most of the time there with the Constructs going through shifts guarding the place...
Have you seen Barbra? I have some updates for her.
Wait, but she's a chef, no?

I know, but she's taken over Julie's place because Assad has apparently vowed for her competency, and part of what we do overlaps with her area of responsibility. I only address her as a chef because that's what everyone else still calls her.
She's probably with Assad.
I'll be right back, then.
The man lowers down and starts checking up on Field.
How you doin', big guy? Got a fever?
No, but I've run out of the medicine.
That's fine. I'll go and exchange some for you. Let's go.
...Exchange?
Yup. Only the doctor up on the upper level has the medicine I need, so we need to go to him to trade in resources for my medicine.
Do you still have any resources left?
Only thing we have left is my mother's bracelet... We'll visit the doctor again in three months, and I'll have to save up enough resources by then.
It's okay, son. You're the only family I have left in the world and I can't afford to lose you.
When do you have to go?
Pretty soon. I have another mission to catch tonight.
Bancroft holds Field up and waves at Noan.
Thank you so much again. We'll see you around.
See ya, Noan.
...See ya.
You probably want to stay away from that Field kid.
Right after Noan finished eating with the gang and was about to get busy with a "mission" from Shauna, Niino drags a chair over and sits before him.
Bancroft has screwed up quite a few times, and they're both troublemakers.
Because he's lost goods?
Not just that. See, there is a lot more than meets the eye to the guy's connection with the guys up there.
Hey, Niino. Glad you're here. Hurry up and help us untangle these yarns.
Shauna throws a torn sweater over at Niino. She asks him to work together with Noan to remove the threads that are still fine, tie them, and ball them up.
He was about to say something—but instead decided to swallow it and work away with Noan.
The guy is fishy with a capital F. See, we've got a few of our men busted already since he came.
They said they'd found evidence of major wrongdoings committed by our guys—but guess who's the one that reported everything to those guys up there without saying a word to Rachel?
And Bancroft isn't the only snitch around. The aristocrats kind of know what we're up to, so they've set up a nice little "system of rewards" in place to turn us against one another down here.
A "system of rewards"? What do you mean?
Look over there.
Down at the end of the car, a guard is dragging a civilian by the hair toward the Industrial Carriage—with another guard taking away all his resources.
People can do anything, so long as there are perks in it for them.
Yo, dude. Hold your horses there and chill out.
Scenes like this are commonplace now, but Noan can never pretend they don't bother him.
Capt told me to not get involved.
He lowers his head in frustration and carries on with work.

Glad you kept your cool. The guy probably lost goods or messed up in the Industrial Carriage. Funny that they never busted him until now, though. The Bumblebees pretty much get paid for slacking off e'erday.
Better hope the odds are ever in your favor, buddy.
Hearing the discussion over here, Weyland turns this way with his bowl in hand.
What? I'm damn clean.

Wow, says the guy who's got both his hands dirty with all the mud? Everything we're doing is breaking the rules! And don't even get me started on the shady things that a bunch of us is doing to keep our heads above water.
And even if we ignore all that for discussion's sake, the guards pay the snitch a cut of the resources they confiscate.
So even if you're as damn clean as you say, people can still drag you through the mire when they get hungry.
Hey, I see you have an empty bowl there. Give us a hand here, will ya?
Shauna tosses another torn sweater to Weyland.
C'mon, I came over with the bowl exactly because I didn't want to get dragged into this.
Weyland protests as he puts down his bowl and joins the ranks of Niino and Noan.
What are these snitches after, though?
Probably the perks they get to have right away. Why give a damn to some long-haul revolution when there are perks you get to enjoy right away, right?
There are tons of scums like Bancroft out there that are willing to do just about anything to save their own butts. I can't believe he's the kid's dad.
I've seen the boy. Cute kid, pretty smart too, and he's almost as well-behaved as Four-Eyes.
Hahaha, but we still need to give Noan some credit here! He's doing so much better now than when he just came.
Shivering from laughing, Shauna slaps Noan on the shoulder.
People change, especially kids.
Birds of a feather flock together, eh?
I gather the kid has been flocking a whole lot with you, then?
Well, not a whole lot, but we do eat together on a regular basis.
Which isn't a bad thing, really. People broaden your world, right?
Word. And where we were just now?
You were just saying how Bancroft can do anything.
Right. Dude has to snitch to survive because he's so at his wit's end.
But everyone is going down together if things down here stay the way they do.
What exactly is to blame, though? The aristocrats? Human nature? Or this hellhole itself?
A bit of each, I guess.
But going back to what I was saying, you want to stay away from Field, Noan. Bancroft is anything but kind.
But that's what you all said about my mom and me.
...We're saying these things for your sake, son!
For... my sake?
People only opened their arms to Noan because he'd stood up for Field.
And there is no way Noan is going to cut ties with Field to earn his place among these people.
You're trying to distance yourself from Field when you were just saying how he's different from his dad.
Why are you taking the kid's side, son?
Because he's my friend, and... I've been in his shoes.
If you can't stop doubting and hating on someone that needs help, how are you going to prove yourself innocent when the table turns somewhere down the road?
Word. I'm blown away, kid. Seems like all the reading is doing wonders here.
C'mon, are you taking the kid's side, too?
See, Noan hangs around Rachel all the time now, and you just never know what Bancroft is gonna do if Noan gets screwed over somewhere down the road.
Y'all still remember what happened to Julie, yeah?
Wait, what...?
Look, son. Just do as we say... if you don't want what happened to your mom to happen to you.
Do you know who killed her, Weyland?
Huh?
Noan does have his own theory about his mother's death—yet he's never had any information to check against his theory, and he never figured out the perp's motive.
How in the world...
Oh, silly me. I gotta get goin' now!
Seemingly perturbed, Weyland puts the sweater down on the table halfway done and makes a run for it before anyone knows what just happened.
